question.title: Object header size in Java on 64bit VM with <4GB RAM

node.contents: I wanted to know if there is some way to have the 64bit VM use 8byte object headers instead of 12byte object headers if the usable RAM for the JVM is 4GB anyway.

astNode.text: I wanted to know if there is some way to have the 64bit VM use 8byte object headers instead of 12byte object headers if the usable RAM for the JVM is 4GB anyway.

node.contents: Or is it like that on Linux, if not on windows? Could someone test this with this code?

astNode.text: Or is it like that on Linux, if not on windows? Could someone test this with this code?

elements.contents: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class ObjectSizes { String s1; String s2; public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { Unsafe unsafe; try { Field field = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (Unsafe)field.get(null); } catch (Exception ex) { throw new RuntimeException("Can't get Unsafe instance.", ex); } Field s1Field = ObjectSizes.class.getDeclaredField("s1"); Field s2Field = ObjectSizes.class.getDeclaredField("s2"); long s1OffSet = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(s1Field); long s2OffSet = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(s2Field); System.out.println("We are running "+System.getProperty("java.version")); System.out.println("Object header size is "+s1OffSet+" bytes."); System.out.println("Object reference size is "+(s2OffSet-s1OffSet)+" bytes."); } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class ObjectSizes { String s1; String s2; public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { Unsafe unsafe; try { Field field = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); unsafe = (Unsafe)field.get(null); } catch (Exception ex) { throw new RuntimeException("Can't get Unsafe instance.", ex); } Field s1Field = ObjectSizes.class.getDeclaredField("s1"); Field s2Field = ObjectSizes.class.getDeclaredField("s2"); long s1OffSet = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(s1Field); long s2OffSet = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(s2Field); System.out.println("We are running "+System.getProperty("java.version")); System.out.println("Object header size is "+s1OffSet+" bytes."); System.out.println("Object reference size is "+(s2OffSet-s1OffSet)+" bytes."); } }

node.contents: It doesn't look like it's possible to have an 8-byte object header on a 64-bit JVM. The header consists of a "mark word", a pointer to the object's class, array size in case of an array, and padding to reach the next 8-byte boundary.

astNode.text: It doesn't look like it's possible to have an 8-byte object header on a 64-bit JVM. The header consists of a "mark word", a pointer to the object's class, array size in case of an array, and padding to reach the next 8-byte boundary.

node.contents:
• The mark word may be used to store native pointers to implement locks and to help GC, so it occupies 8 bytes on a 64-bit JVM.
  • With heaps smaller than 32GB the pointer to the object's class is compressed to 4 bytes.
  • The padding may be used to store one of the fields.

astNode.text:
• The mark word may be used to store native pointers to implement locks and to help GC, so it occupies 8 bytes on a 64-bit JVM.
  • With heaps smaller than 32GB the pointer to the object's class is compressed to 4 bytes.
  • The padding may be used to store one of the fields.

node.contents: Therefore the object header on a 64-bit system can occupy as little as 8 + 4 = 12 bytes, but not less.

astNode.text: Therefore the object header on a 64-bit system can occupy as little as 8 + 4 = 12 bytes, but not less.

node.contents: 1. Using compressed pointers via -XX:+UseCompressedOops (enabled by default on Java 6)

astNode.text: 1. Using compressed pointers via -XX:+UseCompressedOops (enabled by default on Java 6)

node.contents: In that case: object headers will be 12 bytes, array headers will be 16 bytes (last 4 byte for size of array)

astNode.text: In that case: object headers will be 12 bytes, array headers will be 16 bytes (last 4 byte for size of array)

node.contents: In that case: object headers will be 16 bytes, array headers will be 20 bytes (last 4 byte for size of array)

astNode.text: In that case: object headers will be 16 bytes, array headers will be 20 bytes (last 4 byte for size of array)

node.contents: The code given above is not VM bit-size independent and will give different results for 32-bit and 64-bit vms. You need to consider bit-ness and compressed oops factors to compute correct size.

astNode.text: The code given above is not VM bit-size independent and will give different results for 32-bit and 64-bit vms. You need to consider bit-ness and compressed oops factors to compute correct size.

node.contents: Using compressed pointers via -XX:+UseCompressedOops (enabled by default on Java 6)

astNode.text: Using compressed pointers via -XX:+UseCompressedOops (enabled by default on Java 6)

node.contents: This is not true for all version of Java 6. -XX:+UseCompressedOops is enabled by default starting with Java 6u25

astNode.text: This is not true for all version of Java 6. -XX:+UseCompressedOops is enabled by default starting with Java 6u25
